channel.title: Music on Alien Truth Social

item.title: Alien (Britney Spears song)
item.description:
Alien (Britney Spears song) ðŸ”—

“Alien” is a song by Britney Spears from her 2013 album Britney Jean. The song is a mid-tempo dance-pop track about Spears’ feelings of loneliness. It received positive reviews from music critics, who praised its production and personal nature. Despite not being released as a single, it charted on the US Bubbling Under Hot 100 and the French Singles Chart. Spears performed the song during her “Britney: Piece of Me” residency.

Background ðŸ”—

After her time as a judge on The X Factor, Spears began working on her eighth studio album in December 2012. William Orbit was announced as a producer for the project in May 2013. Spears described “Alien,” her collaboration with Orbit, as “really cool” and “really great.” There were initial rumors of a collaboration with Lady Gaga, but this did not happen. A demo version of the song leaked online before the album’s release, which Orbit stated had incorrect chorus notes that were fixed in the final version. Spears considered releasing “Alien” as a single, as revealed in her documentary I Am Britney Jean, but this never materialized. In July 2014, an unedited vocal track of Spears singing the song leaked, drawing criticism for her uncorrected vocals. Orbit defended Spears, stating that the leaked audio was a vocal warm-up and not intended for public release.

Composition ðŸ”—

“Alien” is a midtempo dance-pop song co-written by Spears, William Orbit, Dan Traynor, Ana Diaz, and Anthony Preston, and produced by Orbit and HyGrade. The song’s musical style has been compared to Madonna’s Ray of Light album, which was also produced by Orbit. Lyrically, the song explores themes of loneliness. A vocal glitch at 2:14 in the song sparked discussion, with Orbit joking that it was due to an alien abduction.

Critical Reception ðŸ”—

“Alien” was generally well-received by music critics, who praised its production and personal themes. Critics highlighted Orbit’s production and Spears’ vulnerability on the track. Some reviewers compared the song favorably to Madonna’s work with Orbit. However, one critic felt that Spears’ vocal performance did not match the song’s solemn production.

Live Performances ðŸ”—

Spears performed “Alien” during her “Britney: Piece of Me” residency at Planet Hollywood Las Vegas. One performance was notable because Spears was caught lip-syncing when the backing track continued playing after she missed her cue. The song was later removed from the setlist but was briefly re-added following Spears’ breakup with her boyfriend David Lucado.

Credits and Personnel ðŸ”—

Lists the people involved in the creation of the song, including:

  • Songwriters: Britney Spears, William Orbit, Dan Traynor, Ana Diaz, Anthony Preston
  • Producers: William Orbit, HyGrade
  • Engineers: Alan O’Connell, Alan Tilston, John Hanes, Serban Ghenea
  • Additional Vocals: Ana Diaz

The recording took place at Guerrilla Studios in London and was mixed at MixStar Studios in Virginia Beach, Virginia.

Charts ðŸ”—

“Alien” charted on the French Singles Chart and the US Billboard Bubbling Under Hot 100 chart. It reached number 147 in France and number 8 on the Bubbling Under Hot 100 in the US. It also charted in South Korea, reaching number 90 on the Gaon Music Chart.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_(Britney_Spears_song)

item.title: List of songs about close encounters with aliens
item.description:
List of Songs About Close Encounters with Aliens ðŸ”—

This is a compilation of songs across various decades that explore lyrical themes related to close encounters with extraterrestrial aliens.

1940s ðŸ”—

This section highlights the earliest example on the list, “(When You See) Those Flying Saucers” by The Buchanan Brothers, released in July 1947. Its release coincided with the beginning of the flying saucer era, shortly after the Kenneth Arnold UFO sighting.

1950s ðŸ”—

The 1950s saw a surge in songs about flying saucers and aliens. Notable entries include “The Flying Saucer Parts 1 & 2” by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman, “My Flying Saucer” with lyrics by Woodie Guthrie, “The Purple People Eater” by Sheb Wooley, “Two Little Men In A Flying Saucer” by Ella Fitzgerald, and “Flyin’ Saucers Rock & Roll” by Billy Lee Riley and Jerry Lee Lewis.

1960s ðŸ”—

This section lists songs from the 1960s that touch on extraterrestrial themes. Key songs include “Let There Be More Light” and “Set the Controls for the Heart of the Sun” by Pink Floyd, “Mr. Spaceman” by The Byrds, “Voices Green and Purple” by The Bees, “It Came Out of the Sky” by Creedence Clearwater Revival, “Have You Seen the Saucers” by Jefferson Airplane, and “U.F.O.” by Jim Sullivan.

1970s ðŸ”—

The 1970s brought a diverse range of songs exploring alien encounters. Highlights include “After the Gold Rush” by Neil Young, “Calling Occupants of Interplanetary Craft” by Klaatu (covered by The Carpenters), “Childhood’s End” by Pink Floyd, “Come Sail Away” by Styx, “Here Come the Martian Martians” by Jonathan Richman and the Modern Lovers, “Horsell Commons and the Heat Ray” by Jeff Wayne, “I’ve Seen the Saucers” by Elton John, “Longer Boats” by Cat Stevens, “Martian Boogie” by Brownsville Station, “Mothership Connection” by Parliament, “Starman” by David Bowie, “Starship Trooper” and “Arriving UFO” by Yes, “Waiting for the UFOs” by Graham Parker, “Silver Lights” by Sammy Hagar, “UFO” by Johnny Rivers, “Children of the Sun” by Billy Thorpe, “Starrider” by Foreigner, “Strange Ships” by Fox, and “Ships in the Sky” by Wishbone Ash.

1980s ðŸ”—

This section covers songs from the 1980s with alien or UFO themes. Noteworthy songs include “Fire Of Unknown Origin” by Blue Ã–yster Cult, “Books about UFOs” by HÃ¼sker DÃ¼, “Flying Saucers” by Nina Hagen, “Love Walks In” by Van Halen, “Loving the Alien” by David Bowie, “No Doubt About It” by Hot Chocolate, “Nobody Told Me” by John Lennon, “Rapture” by Blondie, “Zero Zero UFO” by The Ramones, “I Ran (So Far Away)” by A Flock of Seagulls, “Caught in the Crossfire” by April Wine, and “Don’t Be Late” by Saga.

1990s ðŸ”—

The 1990s entries include “The Alien Song (For Those Who Listen)” by Mila Jovovich, “El Aparato (“The Apparatus”)” by CafÃ© Tacvba, “Alien (I Am)” by Hawkwind, “Aliens Exist” by Blink-182, “Alien Visitors” by Man or Astro-man?, “Another Sunday” by I Mother Earth, “Fell in Love with an Alien” by the Kelly Family, “Hangar 18” by Megadeth, “Hat Too Flat” by Walter Becker, “I Made Love to a Martian” by Mustard Plug, “Girl from Mars” by Ash, “Martian Dance Invasion” by Brainiac, “Motorway to Roswell” by Pixies, “Scent of a Mule” by Phish, “Shades of Grey” by Stuart Davis, “Spaceman” by Babylon Zoo, “Subterranean Homesick Alien” by Radiohead, “The Happening” by Pixies, “Who’s There?” by Smash Mouth, “Spaceman” by Bif Naked, “Is That You Mo-Dean?” by The B-52s, “Men in Black” by Will Smith, and “Calgone” by Incubus.

2000s to present ðŸ”—

This section lists songs from the 2000s to the present day. It includes “Fracture” by Edison’s Children (Neil Armstrong’s son’s band), “The Aliens Are Here” by The Hippos, “And You Thought the Doctor’s Probe Hurt” by Belvedere, “Jaadoo, Jaadoo” by Rajesh Roshan, “Concerning the UFO sighting near Highland, Illinois” by Sufjan Stevens, “Aliens” by Doctor Octagon, “UFO” by Sneaky Sound System, “Rosetta Stoned” by Tool, “Fallout of the 4th Kind” by Edison’s Children, “We’re Not Alone” by Nas, “Spaceman” by The Killers, “Venus Ambassador” by Bryan Scary & The Shredding Tears, “E.T.” by Katy Perry featuring Kanye West, “Zopilotes” by CafÃ© Tacuba, “A Million Miles Away (I Wish I Had A Time Machine)” and “The Awakening” by Edison’s Children, “Ancient Aliens” by Lemon Demon, “Decks Dark” by Radiohead, “Hey Aliens” by The Bouncing Souls, “Spaceship” by Kesha, “Herd Culling” by Porcupine Tree, “Silver Circles” by Upchurch, “End of the World” by Tom MacDonald, “Staring at the Stars” by Dan Marfisi and Glenn Jordan, “An Alien Abduction Story (The Probing)” by The Schnooks, and “Down Bad” by Taylor Swift.

Notes ðŸ”—

This section provides a note indicating that certain songs are used as bumper music on the StarTalk podcast UFO episode.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the various sources used to compile the list of songs, including articles from publications like The A.V. Club, Huffington Post, NPR, Salon.com, New York Times, and books on UFOs and alien encounters.

Further reading ðŸ”—

This section suggests a book for further exploration of the topic: Alien Rock: The Rock ’n’ Roll Extraterrestrial Connection by M. Luckman.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/(When_You_See)_Those_Flying_Saucers
